awd_titl_txt: EA: Upgrade of the Laser Heating System in the High-Pressure Diamond-Anvil Cell Laboratory at Arizona State University
awd_abstract_narration:
This Instrumentation and Facilities award, led by PI Shim at Arizona State University(ASU), will upgrade the laser-heating system used in diamond-anvil cell experiments. These types of experiments are crucial for understanding the Earth's deep interior. The proposed enhancements include the abilities to heat Earth materials to very high temperatures, and increase high-precision sample positioning, and high-resolution imaging. These upgrades address current limitations, thereby enabling more advanced research into understanding extreme conditions, like those found in the Earth's deep interior. This upgrade is significant as it will enable researchers to explore the processes and chemical evolution of early Earth, contributing to our broader understanding of planetary formation and evolution. Over the years, Shim's lab has become a nurturing ground for aspiring early career scientists, particularly those from groups historically excluded from STEM, with numerous students advancing to academic institutions, national laboratories, and industry, thereby contributing significantly to fields encompassing not only Earth science but also materials engineering. The upgrade will further expand these educational opportunities, reinforcing ASU's commitment to diversity and excellence in scientific research and education by both advancing scientific understanding and continuing to foster an inclusive environment for future scientists.

This award will upgrade the Shim lab's laser-heating system at ASU to enhance heating quality in diamond-anvil cell experiments, enabling higher temperature heating, independent control of laser power on both sides of the sample, pulsed beams for hydrogen-media experiments, precise sample positioning, and high-resolution imaging. This upgrade is crucial as the current system, relying on a single 100 W fiber optic laser for double-sided heating, limits heating capabilities beyond 3000 K and lacks components for pulsed heating, which is pivotal in studying hydrogen in Earth's deep interior. Implementing these improvement will allow students and postdoctoral researchers to conduct important experiments, to expand understanding of early Earth processes and chemical evolution.Furthermore, the enhancement to the system aligns with the commitment to inclusive research, demonstrated through mentoring and publications involving undergraduate students, particularly those from underrepresented backgrounds. The upgrade will expand undergraduate research opportunities at ASU, furthering diversity in STEM, and particularly benefiting its status as a Hispanic Serving Institution under Title III and Title V programs. Alumni of Shim's lab have pursued advanced degrees and hold notable positions in STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on upgrading the laser heating system for diamond-anvil cell (DAC) experiments at Arizona State University (ASU). The goal of the upgrade was to enable researchers to conduct high-temperature experiments to better understand the Earth’s deep interior, a key area of study in Earth sciences and planetary research. This upgraded system can also facilitate research in other fields, such as condensed matter physics and exoplanet studies, with potential for significant societal impact.

Intellectual Merit

The primary outcome of this project is the enhanced capability of the laser heating system, which now enables higher temperatures, more precise control of thermal gradients, and the ability to heat samples using pulsed lasers. These advancements allow researchers to study materials under extreme conditions similar to those found in the Earth's core and mantle, where temperatures can exceed 3000 K. Such conditions are critical to understanding how the Earth and other planetary bodies evolved.

The upgraded system also provides more accurate sample positioning, improved imaging of laser-heated samples, and the ability to independently control laser power on both sides of a sample. These improvements are crucial for studying the formation of the Earth's core and mantle, and understanding the role of hydrogen in these processes. Furthermore, the addition of pulsed heating opens up new possibilities for investigating hydrogen storage in planetary scale.

Broader Impacts

This project has a broad range of potential impacts beyond its scientific contributions. The upgraded laser heating system at ASU has significantly enhanced research opportunities for students and early-career scientists. Graduate students and postdoctoral researchers can gain valuable hands-on experience in cutting-edge experimental techniques, which is crucial for developing a highly skilled STEM workforce in the United States. PI Shim’s former students and postdocs have gone on to successful careers in industry, contributing to the development of high-strength materials for technologies used in cell phones, computers, and other applications.

Moreover, the research facilitated by this upgraded system has potential applications in other disciplines. For example, the ability to study materials at extreme conditions could lead to breakthroughs in developing new materials for a wide range of industries, including electronics and energy storage. The capabilities of the upgraded system have also opened up new research avenues in exoplanet science, enabling the study of atmosphere-interior interactions on distant planets. These studies could provide insights into the evolution and habitability of exoplanets, with potential applications in future space exploration missions.

 

In conclusion, the upgraded laser heating system at ASU has had a transformative impact on research in Earth sciences, condensed matter physics, and exoplanet studies at Arizona State University. It has provided new opportunities for scientific discovery, expanded the skills and capabilities of students and early-career researchers, and facilitated the development of technologies that could have broad societal benefits. By enhancing the understanding of Earth’s deep interior and enabling the development of new materials, this project lays the groundwork for future advances in science and technology, contributing to the growth of the U.S. scientific workforce and offering important societal impacts in the years to come.
